wikipedia_page.main: Lavender Rosamund Marguerite ("Pinkie") Barnes (18 April 1915 – 14 September 2012) was an English international table tennis champion.Barnes did not like the short forms of any of her three Christian names and was keen to be called a nickname; 'Pinkie' apparently derived from her babyhood complexion. She played for England 11 times between 1946 and 1950 and won various trophies including the Championship of the Netherlands.She was doubles finalist winning a silver medal at the 1949 World Table Tennis Championships with Joan Crosby, they lost in the final to the then World Champion, Hungary's Gizi Farkas and Scot Helen Elliot. Barnes won another silver medal as part of the women's team consisting of Joan Crosby, Margaret Franks and Adele Wood.She was considered particularly glamorous among sports personalities of the late 1940s.In 1952, she married the actor Sam Kydd; their son is the actor Jonathan Kydd.  Following her marriage, Pinkie became an advertising copywriter, working for Masius & Ferguson, and was one of the first women in the UK to hold such a position.

response: * Pinkie Barnes, a table tennis champion who later became a copywriter.

He married Pinkie Barnes, an ex-international table tennis champion (she was World Doubles Finalist in 1948) and one of Britain's first women advertising copywriters. Their son, Jonathan Kydd, followed his father into the acting profession. He has never landed a major role and has very much lived in his family’s shadow.

response: She won double silver at the 1949 World Table Tennis Championships in the women's team event and the women's doubles with Pinkie Barnes.
She won a silver medal at the 1949 World Table Tennis Championships in the Corbillon Cup (women's team event) with Pinkie Barnes, Joan Crosby and Peggy Franks for England.

link_mentions.page: 1949 World Table Tennis Championships – Women's Doubles
response: Gizi Farkas and Helen Elliot defeated Pinkie Barnes and Joan Crosby in the final by three sets to nil.
